docs.lead_paragraph: As a barometer of the quality of health care, the infant mortality rate is an imprecise gauge. Still, as the nation's infant mortality rate has fallen steadily during the last two decades, Americans have come to look upon this indicator as evidence that health conditions are improving. But after years of progress, there are signs that the death rates are edging up again. And some critics say that the Reagan Administration's priorities - its economic policies as well as budget cutbacks that it has sought in health care programs - are to blame.

headline.main: ARE PROGRAM CUTS LINKED TO INCREASED INFANT DEATHS?

docs.lead_paragraph: MARY is a sales manager in a large company. Her husband Joe recently had his appendix removed and the c ompany's health insurance plan paid all $2,000 of his medical costs.T im works with Mary, and his wife recently had a baby. The health p lan paid only $500 of the couple's $2,000 maternity bill. Does the health insurance plan constitute illegal sex discrimination against male employees such as Tim, by making them absorb more of their wives' maternity costs than female employees must absorb of their husbands' medical costs? The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission thinks so, and some time this spring the United States Supreme Court is expected to rule on the issue.
